title.narrative: Supporting Multi-Sector Emergency Response Assistance for Populations Affected by the North-West, South-West Crisis in Cameroon

description.narrative: Humanitarian needs in Cameroon remain high. In the North-West, South-West (NWSW), the socio-political crisis that erupted in 2017 after peaceful protests by lawyers and teachers against a perceived encroachment of the regions' cultural practices and autonomy turned into an armed conflict between government defense forces and Non-State Armed Groups (NSAGs). The conflict has since continued to trigger significant and dynamic internal displacements and related humanitarian needs and shows no signs of de-escalation in the short to medium term. Over the course of 2021, the relationships between NSAG field commanders and members of the diaspora based outside of Cameroon have progressively deteriorated or strained, with diaspora leaders holding less and less influence in coordinating NSAG activities and facilitating humanitarian access, ultimately making humanitarian access negotiations more complex as coordinating with the diaspora no longer consistently secures access. With this project, IOM is contributing to the improvement of living conditions and the well-being of crisis-affected populations in North-West, South-West, Littoral and West regions by addressing the multi-sectoral humanitarian needs of affected populations with integrated programming through providing the humanitarian community with information on displacement trends and most pressing sectoral needs of conflict-affected populations.
